results.description:
**Haiku** is a UNIX-like open source operating system that provides a tool called **_haikuporter_** to build 3rd party open source software.

A **_recipe_** in Haiku is a text file that the **_[haikuporter](https://github.com/haikuports/haikuporter) _** tool reads in order to build open source software and create packages for it.
The collection of recipes that may be built by haikuporter is called **_[HaikuPorts](https://github.com/haikuports/haikuports)_**.

If you are new to Haiku then you should probably start with these tasks:
* [[New to Haiku? Do this one first] Install and Run Haiku](tasks/6259338675486720/)
* [Install and run HaikuPorter](tasks/5198061450559488/)

The goal of this task is to write a recipe for **mlt**

You can find the sources on the project homepage: https://github.com/mltframework/mlt/

The recipe should be added to haikuports at haikuports/media-libs/mlt

Important: please read the generic instructions for "recipe" tasks, as we have a lot of these: https://dev.haiku-os.org/wiki/GoogleCodeInTaskRecipe
results.name: Create a recipe for mlt

results.description:
This task is an introduction to Haiku Layout Management.  For this task, pick one of the open issues below and convert the application to use Layout Management.

https://github.com/HaikuArchives/BeOhms/issues/9
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/DeeperPeople/issues/5
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/BeBattle/issues/6
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/WakeUp/issues/7
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/TimeCop/issues/3
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/Fortuna/issues/5
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/GIGOcalc/issues/3
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/Tolmach/issues/4
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/Toner/issues/4
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/Organizer/issues/8
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/Finance/issues/8
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/TakeNotes/issues/42
https://github.com/HaikuArchives/Peek/issues/9

Here's an article discussing Layout Management and teaching you the basics. https://www.haiku-os.org/documents/dev/laying_it_all_out_part_1/ and https://www.haiku-os.org/docs/api/layout_intro.html

When picking this task, let us know which application you plan to work on.  Submit the url to your pull request that adds this supports.
results.name: Update a Haiku application to use Layout Management

results.description:
HaikuArchives has 300+ applications, many of which were written originally for BeOS.  Haiku added Layout Management, which allows applications to look nicer at different sizes and when using other languages which may have longer or shorter text fields, etc.  

For this task, you will be searching through these old applications to see which of them still need to be updated to support Layout Management.  Check the open issues for the application and if you already see an open issue for it, make a note of the application name, then move on to another one.  When you find one that doesn't have an open issue for it, try installing it using HaikuDepot and then try adjusting your system fonts and opening/closing the application at various sizes.  Also try resizing the window(s) and see if there are any GUI issues such as cutoff text, etc.  When you find one like this, open a new issue on its github page "Update to add support for Layout Management".  Make a note of those as well.  We are looking for 10 that need it, and for you to submit a list of those 10 newly opened issues, along with the list of ones you found that already had support, or already had an open issue for adding it.  This can be just a plain .txt text file.

Here's an article discussing Layout Management to help you identify whether applications have it already or not.
https://www.haiku-os.org/documents/dev/laying_it_all_out_part_1/  and
https://www.haiku-os.org/docs/api/layout_intro.html
results.name: Research Applications on HaikuArchives to see which one(s) still need Layout Management support

results.description:
This task is to pick an open issue in Haiku and to solve it.
https://dev.haiku-os.org/query?status=assigned&status=in-progress&status=new&status=reopened&component=%5EApplications

Your code must meet the Haiku coding guidelines:
https://www.haiku-os.org/development/coding-guidelines
https://dev.haiku-os.org/wiki/CodingGuidelines/SubmittingPatches

For this task, you should have experience compiling Haiku, if not, you might want to do our Compiling Haiku task first. You may want to first ask mentors if they think the task is not too hard for GCI, as some require precise understanding of specific subsystems, or specific equipment to reproduce the bug.
results.name: Fix an open issue in Haiku (2)

results.description:
ResourceEdit was written by Google Code-In students starting in 2012.

Pick one of the open issues for ResourceEdit and solve it.

- Download and compile the application's sources,
- Run the app and reproduce the bug,
- Change the code to fix the problem,
- Test the app again to make sure the problem is gone
- Make a pull request or submit a patch to the application's repository on github so your changes are integrated.

results.description:
ArmyKnife is an application that lets you edit the metadata of audio files.
Update About Window to use BAboutWindow.
BONUS... you might also fix the link to readme docs from the menu so that it opens in a suitable application. 

Here's an article discussing Layout in Haiku:
https://www.haiku-os.org/documents/dev/laying_it_all_out_part_1/

Fix this open issue for ArmyKnife.
- https://github.com/HaikuArchives/ArmyKnife/
- https://github.com/HaikuArchives/ArmyKnife/issues/44

To complete this task you will need to:

- Run the app and reproduce the bug,
- Change the code to fix the problem,
- Test the app again to make sure the problem is gone.
- Make a pull request or submit a patch to the ArmyKnife repository on GitHub so your changes are integrated.

results.description:
LibWalter is a collection of classes for Haiku adding some missing widgets and controls missing from the standard BeOS/Haiku API.  For this task, write a demo applications which shows some of these in action.  The demo application should be written with the ability to allow adding more features to it to allow showing all or most of the features in the LibWalter library.  See for example the demo Playground in Haiku, found on the deskbar menu Demo/Playground, with source code found in Haiku.

Submit your code as a new pull request on the LibWalter github page, put it in a demo directory.

https://github.com/HaikuArchives/LibWalter
results.name: Write a demo application showing off LibWalter features

results.description:
In order to ensure high quality of our releases, we need to have a comprehensive test suite to run against release candidates.

The goal of this task is to create 3 test cases for *bundled applications or preflets* of your choice. See provided example for a template and attach all 3 test cases in one text file (Markdown formatted). Additionally, provide test result for each test case (passed, failed) you created in Notes section (with hrev tested). If the result is failure, create a bug report.

To come up with ideas you can use Haiku User Guide (for feature tests) or Haiku bug tracker (for regression tests - put a link to the bug in Notes section).

A test case should be 100% reproducible and tested functionality as small as possible but not smaller. Each test case can be for a different app/preflet. Hardware tests are not in scope of this task.

To avoid duplicating work check http://qa.kacperkasper.pl/cases/search/ to see existing tests.

Example test case: http://qa.kacperkasper.pl/case/2/
results.name: Create 3 test cases for Haiku applications or preflets of your choice

The French normalization committee Afnor recently normalized an updated version of the Azerty keymap.

Since most documentation about it is in French you will need to understand it.

https://norme-azerty.fr/

https://springcomp.github.io/optimized-azerty-win/index.html

You task is to write an Azerty+ keymap source file to add to the Haiku sources.
results.name: Create an Azerty+ keymap

The collection of recipes that may be built by haikuporter is called **_[HaikuPorts](https://github.com/haikuports/haikuports)_**.

The recipe should be added to haikuports at haikuports/dev-vcs/qgit

Important: please read the generic instructions for "recipe" tasks, as we have a lot of these: https://dev.haiku-os.org/wiki/GoogleCodeInTaskRecipe
results.name: Create a recipe for QGit

results.description:
The Haiku website mentions various versions of gcc in several pages. Only two should be there: gcc2, which is used for compatibility with BeOS, and gcc8, which is the modern compiler currently used. But over the years, whenever gcc was updated, versions 4, 5, 6 and 7 were mentionned on the website and not all pages were updated.

The goal of this task is to review all the website pages to find all mentions of these now unused versions of gcc and replace them with gcc8. You will want to use "git grep" or a similar search tool to easily locate all occurences of this.
results.name: Review gcc versions mentionned on the website

results.description:
For this task you will be searching for some old (mostly SDL and Allegro related games) ports that were published on BeBits for BeOS in the past, a list can be found at ["web archive"](http://web.archive.org/web/20040810182854/http://www.bebits.com/devprofile/1716)

Some of these ports have already been added to ["haikuports"](https://github.com/haikuports/haikuports) and or ["HaikuArchives"](https://github.com/HaikuArchives) but still a lot are missing, your task consists of finding the sources and add them to "HaikuArchives" (BeOS only related sources) or create a recipe on "haikuports" (multi platform source).

This task is to locate one of these of your choosing and to then locate where the source code for it is today, write a haikuporter recipe that builds it and file a pull request at haikuports. 
When claiming task let us know which one you will be working on and add a link to the eventual PR you made at haikuports.

If you are new to Haiku then you should probably start with these tasks:
* [[New to Haiku? Do this one first] Install and Run Haiku](tasks/6259338675486720/)
* [Install and run HaikuPorter](tasks/5198061450559488/)
results.name: Find abandoned BeOS ports listed on web archive (4)

You will have to use the master branch or patch the last release as the port has just been upstreamed.

The recipe should be added to haikuports at haikuports/app-accessibility/brltty

Important: please read the generic instructions for "recipe" tasks, as we have a lot of these: https://dev.haiku-os.org/wiki/GoogleCodeInTaskRecipe
results.name: Create a recipe for brltty

results.description:
**Haiku** is a UNIX-like open source operating system that provides a tool called **_haikuporter_** to build 3rd party open source software.

A **_recipe_** in Haiku is a text file that the **_[haikuporter](https://github.com/haikuports/haikuporter) _** tool reads in order to build open source software and create packages for it.
The collection of recipes that may be built by haikuporter is called **_[HaikuPorts](https://github.com/haikuports/haikuports)_**.

If you are new to Haiku then you should probably start with these tasks:
* [[New to Haiku? Do this one first] Install and Run Haiku](tasks/6513583765585920/)
* [Install and run HaikuPorter](tasks/5632161987166208/)

The goal of this task is to fix the recipe for **scourge** such that it finds the data files needed to run the game

There is an open PR for scourge that you can find at: https://github.com/haikuports/haikuports/pull/3483

A recipe for the data files has already been added to haikuports: https://github.com/haikuports/haikuports/pull/3484

The recipe should end up at haikuports at haikuports/games-roguelike/scourge

Important: please read the generic instructions for "recipe" tasks, as we have a lot of these: https://dev.haiku-os.org/wiki/GoogleCodeInTaskRecipe
results.name: Fix find data files for scourge
